dublinCore.title: 113 HR 1348 IH: Great Bend of the Gila National Monument Establishment Act
dublinCore.rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Grijalva introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Natural Resources

form.official-title: To establish the Great Bend of the Gila National Monument in the State of Arizona, and for other purposes.

subsection.text: This Act may be cited as the Great Bend of the Gila National Monument Establishment Act .
The table of contents for this Act is as follows:

toc.toc-entry: Sec. 1. Short title; table of contents.
Sec. 2. Establishment of Great Bend of the Gila National Monument, Arizona.
Sec. 5. Tribal use of national monument.
Sec. 6. Off-road use of motorized and mechanized vehicles.
Sec. 8. Research, education, and visitor services.

section.header: Establishment of Great Bend of the Gila National Monument, Arizona

subsection.text: There is established in the State of Arizona the Great Bend of the Gila National Monument (in this Act referred to as the national monument).
The purpose of the national monument is—

paragraph.text: to preserve, protect, and restore the archaeological, cultural, historic, geologic, hydrologic, natural, educational, and scenic resources of the Great Bend of the Gila (Gila River in Western Maricopa County, Arizona) and adjacent land; and
to provide for public interpretation and recreation consistent with the resources described in paragraph (1).

The national monument consists of approximately 84,296 acres of public lands and interests in land administered by the Secretary of the Interior through the Bureau of Land Management, as generally depicted on the map entitled Great Bend of the Gila National Monument and dated March 6, 2013.

The Secretary may make minor adjustments to the boundaries of the national monument to reflect the inclusion of significant archaeological resources discovered after the date of enactment of this Act on public lands adjacent to the national monument.

The map described in paragraph (1) and the legal description of any adjustments made under paragraph (2) shall be on file and available for public inspection in the appropriate offices of the Bureau of Land Management.

subsection.text: Nothing in this Act—

paragraph.text: creates a protective perimeter or buffer zone around the national monument; or
affects private property outside of the boundaries of the national monument.

subsection.text: The Secretary of the Interior shall manage the national monument as part of the National Landscape Conservation System—

paragraph.text: in accordance with this Act and other laws generally applicable to the national monument, including the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act (25 U.S.C. 3001 et seq.) and the policy described in Public Law 95–341 (commonly known as the American Indian Religious Freedom Act; 42 U.S.C. 1996).

subsection.text: In managing the national monument, the Secretary of the Interior shall—

paragraph.text: maintain the undeveloped character of the national monument to the maximum extent practicable; and
protect and restore cultural resources, species, and ecosystems of the national monument.
The Secretary of the Interior—

subparagraph.text: shall conduct an inventory of invasive plant species in the national monument; and
may carry out vegetation management treatments in the national monument.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall utilize native plant species in planning for restoration projects to be conducted in the national monument.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall permit grazing in the national monument, where grazing was established before the date of enactment of this Act—

paragraph.text: subject to all applicable laws; and
consistent with the purposes for which the national monument is established.

subsection.text: Management of the national monument shall support backcountry hunting and other non-motorized recreation in the national monument.

Not later than three years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary of the Interior shall develop a management plan for the national monument that addresses the actions necessary to protect the resources described in section 2(b)(1). The management plan shall include a transportation plan, including travel restrictions and road closures.

In addition to the period of public comment required by subsection (b), the Secretary of the Interior shall prepare the management plan in government-to-government consultation with Indian tribes with a cultural or historic tie to the Great Bend of the Gila.
The Secretary of the Interior shall allow for the continued use of the national monument by members of Indian tribes—

paragraph.text: for traditional ceremonies; and
as a source of traditional plants and other materials.

subsection.text: Tribal use of the national monument under subsection (a) shall be—

paragraph.text: subject to any terms and conditions the Secretary of the Interior determines to be necessary to further the purposes for which the national monument is established; and
in accordance with applicable law.

subsection.text: Nothing in this Act affects—

paragraph.text: the rights of any Indian tribe on Indian land;
any individually held trust land or Indian allotment; or
any treaty rights providing for nonexclusive access to or in the national monument by members of Indian tribes for traditional and cultural purposes.

section.header: Off-road use of motorized and mechanized vehicles
section.text: Except as needed for administrative purposes or to respond to an emergency, the use of motorized and mechanized vehicles in the national monument is limited to roads and trails designated for their use.

Establishment of the national monument shall not be construed to impact or impose any altitude, flight, or other airspace restrictions on current or future military operations or missions. Should the Armed Forces require additional or modified airspace after the date of the enactment of this Act, Congress does not intend for the establishment of the national monument to impede the Secretary of Defense from petitioning the Federal Aviation Administration to change or expand restricted military airspace.

subsection.text: The Secretary of the Interior shall provide such minimal facilities within the national monument for education and interpretation, such as signage or other interpretive kiosks, as the Secretary considers necessary for visitor enjoyment of the national monument, while ensuring the protection of monument resources.
Any visitor center for the national monument shall be sited in a community in the vicinity of the national monument, rather than within the boundaries of the national monument.

paragraph.text: The Secretary of the Interior shall allow scientific research to be conducted in the national monument, including research to identify, protect, and preserve the historic and cultural resources of the monument.

The Secretary may conduct, or authorize other persons to conduct, research regarding the effects of climate change on monument resources to develop management techniques to boost resiliency and facilitate adaptation to human-caused climate change.

section.text: Nothing in this Act affects the jurisdiction of the State of Arizona with respect to the management of fish and wildlife on public lands in the State.

subsection.text: The Secretary of the Interior may acquire land and any interest in land, State and private, within or adjacent to the boundaries of the national monument—

paragraph.text: by purchase from willing sellers with donated or appropriated funds;
by donation; or
by exchange.

subsection.text: Land and interests in land acquired under the authority of subsection (a) shall automatically become part of the national monument.
Subject to valid existing rights, all Federal land within the national monument (including any land or interest in land acquired after the date of enactment of this Act) is withdrawn from—

paragraph.text: entry, appropriation, or disposal under the public land laws;
location, entry, and patent under the mining laws; and
operation of the mineral leasing, mineral materials, and geothermal leasing laws.

subsection.text: Subject to valid and existing rights, renewable energy and transmission development is prohibited in the national monument.
Nothing in this Act affects any valid water rights, including water rights held by the United States.
The designation of the national monument does not create a Federal reserved water right.

text.cato:entity: There are authorized to be appropriated such sums as are necessary to carry out this Act .
